title: 2016 Lecture 05: Maps of Meaning: Part I: Anomaly and the brain
description:
We have limited knowledge. In consequence, many things are unknown and unpredictable. However, we must still act when we don't know what to do. Much of the human brain is therefore devoted towards processing novelty or anomaly, which emerge when the plans we make to fulfill our desires go wrong.

So momentarily we’re going to return to

I want to talk to you today about how your

The first thing I’d like to point out, is
we talked about the difference between Darwinian

One claim that you might make if you were

Then I want to show you, I hope, that the

People think about reality in objective terms,

I think that’s a limited viewpoint, a powerful
but limited viewpoint.

I think it’s much more realistic to assume
that whatever reality is, is more like a continual
interplay of very, very complex patterns.

I suppose you could make the case that those
patterns are ultimately made out of particles,

That’s part of the atomic theory is that

atomic particles, but that they’re arrayed

If they’re arrayed in space, that means

And if you reduce the phenoma to the particle,
without taking into account the patterning

levels and levels and levels of information

Those levels of information are – they may

Alright, so we’ll start with the neuropsychological

They’re units of conception and emotion

Now I think what we’ll do with regards to

It’s appropriate to start from the bottom
